Award.AwardTitle: Metabolic Pathway Analysis 2017 Conference Proposal; Bozeman, Montana; June 24-28, 2017

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Carlson, Ross P.
Proposal Number: 1660493

Partial support for the Metabolic Pathway Analysis conference to be held at Montana State University is expected to bring together leading researchers and developing research students that will facilitate exchange of ideas on the very important topic of pathway analysis. The funding will facilitate participation of at least 140 researchers.

The Metabolic Pathway Analysis (MPA) conference series is an international meeting for the topological study of metabolic networks. MPA 2017 will be held July 24-28, 2017 at Montana State University (MSU), Bozeman and will be the sixth meeting in the biennial conference series. The focus will be on decoding biological principles of metabolic network structure and function using quantitative approaches in conjunction with experimental data. The funding will support the participation of international experts in metabolic network analysis by creating 8 invited speaker awards, facilitating graduate student participation by providing 32 awards covering the cost of meals at an MSU cafeteria, and broaden general participation by partially covering MSU dormitory housing costs for all attendees. The major goals of this conference proposal are to disseminate US-based scientist?s research to an international audience through a combination of oral and poster presentations, educate US-based scientists in the latest metabolic systems analysis technologies and support career development for scientists at all professional stages through face-to-face discussions with international scientists. The NSF support will be leveraged with other research funds including sponsorship by the MSU Center for Biofilm Engineering, MSU Thermal Biology Institute and the MSU Society of Women Engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The Metabolic Pathway Analysis (MPA) conference series is a premier, international meeting for the topological study of metabolic networks. MPA 2017 was held July 24-28, 2017 at Montana State University (MSU), Bozeman and was the sixth meeting in the biennial conference series. MPA 2017 focused on decoding biological principles of metabolic network structure and function using advanced mathematical approaches and computational modeling in conjunction with experimental data. Conference topics spanned the gamut of fundamental and applied biology including biofuels, photosynthesis, multicellular systems, environmental nutrient cycles, and human health. MPA 2017 attracted a highly interdisciplinary group of ~90 international biologists, computer scientists, engineers and mathematicians for formal and informal discussions focused on state-of-the-art advances in metabolic network analysis methodology, theory and application. MPA 2017 was the first from the conference series to be held in North America.

This NSF conference proposal supported the participation of international experts in metabolic network analysis by creating 8 invited speaker awards, facilitating graduate student participation by providing 25 awards covering the cost of meals at an MSU cafeteria, and broaden general participation by partially covering MSU dormitory housing costs for all attendees. The major goals of this conference proposal were to 1) disseminate US-based scientists’ cutting-edge research to an international audience through a combination of oral and poster presentations, 2) educate US-based scientists in the latest metabolic systems analysis technologies and 3) support career development for scientists at all professional stages through face-to-face discussions with international scientists. The NSF support was leveraged with other research funds including sponsorship by the MSU Center for Biofilm Engineering, MSU Thermal Biology Institute, the MSU Society of Women Engineers and the Biochemical Society. 

Broader Impacts:

MPA conferences are structured to be highly interactive. Cutting-edge research discussions during MPA 2017 were encouraged through formal plenary sessions and poster sessions as well as through informal interactions. For instance, all conference attendees stayed at the same MSU dormitory and shared their meals in the same MSU cafeteria. This conference format facilitated learning and communication by integrating researchers at all stages of their careers including industrial scientists, professors, junior faculty members, post-doctoral research scientists and graduate students. The interactions are transformative for scientists looking to be educated in the newest systems biology theories and looking for new collaborative research opportunities as well as for scientists networking for employment opportunities. The organizing committee gave special consideration to underrepresented groups, junior faculty, post-doctoral researchers, graduate students and industrial scientists for oral and poster presentations.

A number of the conference presentations were recorded and are available to the public at the conference website along with a list of attendees, a conference program and other educational material (http://www.chbe.montana.edu/biochemenglab/MPA2017.html).
